excerpts: The gambas al ajillo (shrimp with garlic and butter sauce) was good but nothing special.
gambas al ajillo.author: Chau H.
gambas al ajillo.review:
The first time I visited this establishment, we were denied because it was 10:40pm and they close at 11:00pm. It was interesting because the hostess gave us a table but a waitress came over and said "No, no. We are closed. The kitchen is closed." No apologies, just flat out denial. 

"If at first you don't succeed, dust yourself off and try again." Right? Right. So now I'm back and this time we arrived earlier and were seated right away. We sat in the back of the restaurant which was quite disappointing because the room was too dark. I struggled to read the menu and enjoy the food since our table was only lit by a tiny candle. One star down.

When it came to the food, the chips and salsa were a-ok. The salsa tasted like a fusion of canned tomatoes and ketchup, which I can assure you is not a good combination. Two stars down. However, the green salsa was good and extra spicy. The chips were super crunchy and highly addictive. 

For starters, we had the chicharrones and I felt it was overpowered with cumin. It was crispy but too salty. The gambas al ajillo (shrimp with garlic and butter sauce) was good but nothing special. It's paired with flour tortillas and that made it fun to eat. 

On to the main courses. We had enchiladas, tamales, tacos, and flautas. What a disappointment. The dishes were bland and tasteless. We had to add salt to every single serving and that is a no, no in my book.  Although the portions are big, it did not make up for the mediorce options on the menu. Three stars down.

As for service, our waitress was very sweet and attentive. She always made sure we had our refills on drinks, tortillas, and chips and salsa. We didn't try their margaritas but overheard from the two tables next to us that they were "pretty damn strong." Too bad I won't be coming back to give you an updated review on that.

I should of known that it wasn't meant for me to try the food here when we were already denied the first time around. That was a sign and I should of trusted it instead of shopping for a restaurant on an empty stomach.

excerpts: Per some Yelp recommendations I got the Sampler this time - THANKS GUYS, it was the best idea ever.
sampler.author: Megan A.
sampler.review:
WHOA on the harsh reviews!  Complaining that a drink is *too* strong? Get the heck outta here!  And making fun of the sweet elderly waitress with the hearing aid, would you be happier if she were working in the back stuffing empanadas or something? I mean jeez have a little bit of patience and compassion.   

I feel like this is kinda like saying "they had great water!" but their quesadillas are off the hook!!!  I usually scoff at corn tortillas, but they are what MAKE the quesadillas here.  I have never ordered the one with meat, because the cheesy oozy buttery one gives me lady wood every time.  The thing is though, you gotta eat it FAST because it's only "last meal" worthy if you eat it right when they place it on the table...honestly if you could snatch a piece while the waitress/er is placing it on your table that's the sweet spot.  

Per some Yelp recommendations I got the Sampler this time - THANKS GUYS, it was the best idea ever.  Everything on it was deep-fried except for maybe the quesadilla and the burritos, and I didn't even have to choose between chicken or beef because I was brought 2 of each in the form of spinach and tomato tortillas, and when I dropped my taquito in my margarita on accident, I was brought 2 new taquitos (cause 1 on a plate would be lonely) AND a new margarita!

sampler.author: David D.
sampler.review:
This place was jumping on Friday night. 

After a reception at the deYoung, we decided to go over to Tia Margarita and have some fun. This was the culmination of years' worth of My Lady's raving about the place. When we walked through the door we discovered the place was packed. Three dining rooms or more, and nearly every seat was filled. 

We started off by ordering a couple of margaritas, naturally. Then I ordered the appetizer sampler, and My Lady ordered her current favorite, flautas. While I found that by the end of the sampler plate it seemed like I was eating an endless plate of flour tortillas, My Lady said the flautas were the best she'd ever had. We settled the bill at $59 + a generous tip, because our waiter was truly interested in making sure we had a good time. 

While we had different opinions about the food, we both agreed that the people-watching was outstanding.

sampler.author: Jason C.
sampler.review:
Tia Margarita is easy to miss. It looks like a house, doesn't have loud mariachi music blaring from inside, and doesn't blast the streets with lights. 

I walked in here with a friend after passing by numerous times. We ordered the appetizer combo and a Margarita. While we waited, we sipped on our drinks and ate some chips. They offered two salsas, a mango fruit flavored one and a spicy one. Both were good, but I preferred the fruit flavored one. You can also combine them for the best of both worlds.

When our food arrived, It turned out a lot better than I expected. We received small burritos, a quesadilla, empanadas, and a few other assortments that I forget. Good sizes, easily shared, and good quality. It wasn't the most authentic Mexican I've ever eaten, but for Americanized Mexican, it was pretty darn good -- a LOT better than Chevy's or any of the other chains. 

I left happy and decided I'd go back with more friends. The second time I went, we sat at the bar. I'll admit, I don't remember much. The bartender was nice, the drinks were generous, and the food didn't end up on the street, if you know what I mean.

Update (4/5/08) - I went back and it was a mad house. The waiters forgot our orders,  bartenders ignored us, and it was not quite the same experience. The margaritas were actually pretty bad? So we ordered some top shelf to see if there would be a difference -- nope. The food quality was different, too! Our sampler's empanada's looked like fried cheese bread. Maybe it was a weekend, but this inconsistancy is scary. I'm downgrading my rating...

excerpts: For a change of pace, try the Guatemalan Tostada.
guatemalan tostada.author: Ben S.
guatemalan tostada.review:
People in the Richmond don't have alot of choices for Mexican dining so it's no surprise when we get excited over the average fare at Tia's. Nothing wrong with the food here or the drinks but nothing deserving hyperbole either.

Large, dimly lit and casual, Tia is a fine place to bring a group of mates or your family. If you're alone, sit at the bar and talk to the locals. If you're with friends-of-friends (or worse, with your significant other's co-workers ;) ) asked to be sit up front in a booth. This is so you can see the flat-screen television, where baseball, basketball and other sports spool endlessly.

Regarding Tia vs Tommy's, without question Tommy's makes better margaritas but their food has a Yucatanean bent to it. This wonderful in it's own right but if what you're in the mood for is a more basic restaurant burrito, taco, etc you might find Tia more appealing.

Suggestions: if asked if you want hot or mild salsa get both. The hot is quite hot for some people but the mild has almost no heat (though it's tasty). For a change of pace, try the Guatemalan Tostada. It's topped with chunks of their Pollo Asada and the pineapple/sour dressing they pour over it really works well. You'll be greeted by an enormous mound of lettuce that may make you wonder if you did the right thing by listening to me, but dig deep down and you'll find there's black beans and lots of jack cheese sandwiched between two flour tortillas - more than enough substantial food to fill your tummy and then some.

tia tostada.author: Hayley D.
tia tostada.review:
We came here around 4pm on a Sunday for an early dinner/late lunch. We were really in the mood for Mexican food and a friend mentioned that this place was good. 

Ambiance: Inside it was dim & clean. It looked super small when you walk in, but when we went to our table we saw how there was a lot more space toward the back of the restaurant. 

Service: Service was great here! We got seated right away- even though we came early. Chips were brought out immediately and waters as well. Our server was really nice and knew every thing about the menu- had a lot to suggest for vegetarian/ pescatarians.

Food: The food here was tasty and the plates were HUGE! We started with margaritas- they were pretty plain, but got the job done ;) They should put more lime juice in them for sure. I got a Tia Tostada with no meat and my boyfriend got enchiladas with shrimp for the filling. I tried a bite and the shrimp had such good flavor- they were rich in garlic, white wine, and butter and the outside enchilada sauce was to die for. The tostada was a little plain, I knew I should of gotten the shrimp tostada- NEXT TIME! 

For sure will be back! :) 4.5 stars!

steak picado.author: Sarah M.
steak picado.review:
Freaking love this place. I come here once a week, and that's only because I don't want to appear overzealous. It's not that the food and drink are the best ever, there's just something about this place that makes you want to be a regular.

The chicken fajita meat is fantastic and used in several of the entree's. Just the right mix of citrus and cumin and some other stuff I can't identify but know it tastes damn good. It's especially yum in the Jenni's Special, which is a salad dish and my jam when I'm trying to feel healthy. Black beans, lettuce, chicken, tiny diced jalapenos, and tons of cheese with some sort of creamy dressing that I never use. Also good are the burritos, ground beef tacos, and steak picado.

Sit at the bar, order a large Margarita - no salt, on the rocks, snack on the chips and tomato-y delicious salsa, order something with fajita meat, and make friends with the bartenders. You'll want to come back every Sunday.

This was my order.
The shrimp were garlicky and buttery.
The chicken had a good char and flavor.
The steak was slightly tough, but still good.
pollo asada.author: Elena N.
pollo asada.review:
The roommate was craving Mexican food. Enchiladas to be exact. We decided to pick up Tia Margarita on the way home. I called to place the order when he picked me up downtown. The order was ready about 10 minutes after we arrive.

*Chips and Salsas
If we ate here, they would have given us chips and salsa, so I'm happy they were nice enough to pack some. There's two different salsa. One is spicy and packs a kick! My mouth actually felt like it was on fire towards the end of our meal. I wasn't expecting that. Mixing the two makes for a good balance.

All orders are served with rice, salad and your choice of refried or black beans (we got refried beans with everything):

*Chef's special combo ($22.75): One third each - Carne asada, Pollo asada, Gambas
This was my order. The shrimp were garlicky and buttery. The chicken had a good char and flavor. The steak was slightly tough, but still good. You can ask for corn or flour tortillas with this plate.

*Enchiladas (2) $13.75: corn tortillas rolled around shredded beef and covered with a mild red chili sauce and melted jack cheese
The roommate's. He didn't like this as the sauce was way too thick. Had the consistency of a lighter peanut butter which just tasted weird.

*Chimichanga (1) $13.25: crisp large flour tortilla rolled around chicken and rice with guacamole (no sour cream)
It's kind of bland with just the rice and chicken filling. Super oily as well.

I'd say the food deserves about 3 stars, but the server taking care of me was super nice! Asked me if I wanted more salsa, utensils and napkins, etc. Most places wouldn't care when it comes to take out orders. But the server that helped me out bumped this review up to 4 stars!

excerpts: I always go with my go to dish here, the Pollo Asada plate which had three large chicken breast seasoned just perfect and grilled, with rice and beans.
It's absolutely amazing.
Simply one of the best, most easy dishes but yet Tiá Margarita finds a way to make it that much better.
I have never once left this restaurant hungry for more food.
pollo asada.author: Jason F.
pollo asada.review:
Tia Margarita is by far one of the best consistent Mexican restaurants in San Francisco. I frequent this restaurant often knowing that everything I never leave disappointed or hungry.

The portions are large, like any traditional Mexican restaurant, but what really sets this apart from the standard ole Mexican cuisine, us Californians have come to love is the spices and flavor. 

I always go with my go to dish here, the Pollo Asada plate which had three large chicken breast seasoned just perfect and grilled, with rice and beans. It's absolutely amazing. Simply one of the best, most easy dishes but yet Tiá Margarita finds a way to make it that much better. I have never once left this restaurant hungry for more food. Matter of a fact I always leave with leftovers which is just as good the next day as it was the night before.

If you happen to be In the area don't miss the opportunity to enjoy the tasty, delicious and hearty entrees coming out of the kitchen of Tia Margarita!

but I should add that the garlic sauce used for the shrimp was superb.

It was incredibly loud there and very busy.
I doubt I would go back to be honest.
Just not worth it.

pollo asada.review:

The food...well it was just okay and way overpriced. The carne and pollo asada were incredibly bland. Oh but I should add that the garlic sauce used for the shrimp was superb. But who serves rice pilaf at a Mexican restaurant? 
It was incredibly loud there and very busy.  I doubt I would go back to be honest. Just not worth it.

This is our favorite place to go for fresh lime margaritas (do not get me started on the Tommy v. Tia margarita argument). Order the Jenny's salad with gambas dressing or anything with gambas dressing. Get a burrito with pollo asada or carne asada or have them as entrees. The best! 

Go to trivia the first Thursday of every month and realize you are not as smart as you think you are...Ger is tough!

pollo asada.author: Bill H.
pollo asada.review: I had to post this review after reading some of the negative ones just to put my two cents in. I have been going to Tia Margarita for over twenty years, (I miss Virginia, the late owner terribly)  including after I moved to the East Bay because it represents value and a guaranteed good time. I typically bring friend's and family that are in town for a visit and have yet to hear a complaint from anyone. Francisco behind the bar - hooking up the wicked margaritas is worth the trip alone. I am particualrly fond of the Chef's Special combo platter - huge, HOT plate of Pollo Asada, Garlic Prawns and the best Carne Asada (drenched in onions which seem to be cilantro, lime infused - SO GOOD). I seldom wander from this dish unless it's just to get the Carne Asada dinner plate alone. One day I will try something else.....I have another 20 or 30 good years though to get to the rest of the menu. I have never received anything other than exeplary service, though as a long-time customer, that may have something to do with it.  Either way, I don't care. It is my mexican establishment of choice and will remain so until, well hopefully, forever. As a matter of fact - I am driving to the City now - NCAA tournament be damned (that's what DVR's are for).

excerpts: My favorite is the Pollo Asada (chicken with spices) and the Gambas (prawns marinated in a garlic, white wine sauce).
pollo asada.author: Kimberly R.
pollo asada.review:
A great place for Mexican food. Please do not mistake this for Tex-Mex. We are talking PACIFIC MEXICAN food. Their margaritas are to die for! My favorite is the Pollo Asada (chicken with spices) and the Gambas (prawns marinated in a garlic, white wine sauce). The portions are huge, so bring your appetite or remember to ask for a doggie bag.

This place has been in business for 40 years. It's a huge local spot. It gets busy, but you can call for reservations. If you have to wait for a table, belly up to the bar, get a margarita, and have fun with your friends.

excerpts: Some of my favorites are the pollo asada and the chicken tacos.
The service varies, but is overall average.
pollo asada.author: Jessica B.
pollo asada.review: Great Mexican Food.  Some of my favorites are the pollo asada and the chicken tacos.  The service varies, but is overall average.

excerpts: I had a chimichanga and it was exactly as you'd expect.
chimichanga.author: Jeffrey S.
chimichanga.review:
If you're looking for an opinion on the food, read on. Booze? I'm no help.

What I can say, is that while they're not re-defining the bounds of Mexican food, you can find a classic Mexican restaurant menu here. You know the kind: enchiladas, burritos, tacos, chiles rellenos; the old reliables. You get a bunch of chips and salsa to your table, and one of them was a bit too hot for me, but it will burn your mouth in the best way. They don't want to be precious or fancy, they just want to be an old school neighborhood spot.

That's what they are: a neighborhood spot. On a Saturday evening in the neighborhood I noticed a lot of families coming in. Granted, it was early for dinner. Like, embarrassingly early. But they definitely had a full house by 6pm, and it wasn't rowdy, rather neighbors filing in. 

It's simple, they have a really great neon sign out front, and some old school booths as well as a dining area on the non-bar side of the building. the bar is a cool little wrap area, and they were stuffed to the gills with margarita glasses and limes. Even though I'm not a drinker, I can tell they do a serious business of margaritas. They have all the usual suspects on the menu, all the normal Mexican beers, and from the looks of the marg glasses, you can order a bunch and enjoy the night just fine.

I had a chimichanga and it was exactly as you'd expect. But it was well-made, simple, and didn't cost an arm and a leg. 

The comparison to Tommy's is inevitable, so I'll throw in my non-alcoholic two cents: I'd much rather eat here than there. The alco-philes can argue the maragaritas and tequilas all day without my input, but food wise it really was no contest. Neither is really meant to be just about the food, but I'd go here again for the big portions of Mexican food and the hustle of a Richmond neighborhood restaurant setting.

excerpts: *Chimichanga (1) $13.25: crisp large flour tortilla rolled around chicken and rice with guacamole (no sour cream)
It's kind of bland with just the rice and chicken filling.
chimichanga.author: Elena N.
chimichanga.review:
The roommate was craving Mexican food. Enchiladas to be exact. We decided to pick up Tia Margarita on the way home. I called to place the order when he picked me up downtown. The order was ready about 10 minutes after we arrive.

*Chips and Salsas
If we ate here, they would have given us chips and salsa, so I'm happy they were nice enough to pack some. There's two different salsa. One is spicy and packs a kick! My mouth actually felt like it was on fire towards the end of our meal. I wasn't expecting that. Mixing the two makes for a good balance.

All orders are served with rice, salad and your choice of refried or black beans (we got refried beans with everything):

*Chef's special combo ($22.75): One third each - Carne asada, Pollo asada, Gambas
This was my order. The shrimp were garlicky and buttery. The chicken had a good char and flavor. The steak was slightly tough, but still good. You can ask for corn or flour tortillas with this plate.

*Enchiladas (2) $13.75: corn tortillas rolled around shredded beef and covered with a mild red chili sauce and melted jack cheese
The roommate's. He didn't like this as the sauce was way too thick. Had the consistency of a lighter peanut butter which just tasted weird.

*Chimichanga (1) $13.25: crisp large flour tortilla rolled around chicken and rice with guacamole (no sour cream)
It's kind of bland with just the rice and chicken filling. Super oily as well.

I'd say the food deserves about 3 stars, but the server taking care of me was super nice! Asked me if I wanted more salsa, utensils and napkins, etc. Most places wouldn't care when it comes to take out orders. But the server that helped me out bumped this review up to 4 stars!

excerpts: My friend really enjoyed her shredded beef chimichanga combo plate too.
Full bellies and content tastebuds all around.
chimichanga.author: Liz G.
chimichanga.review:
We have come back a few times since the bad experience previously and have had better service. We walked in around 8:30pm on a Friday and it was busy as usual! The hostess said 30 minute wait, totally understandable. So we ordered drinks at the bar with Francisco before our table was ready. The hostess really stepped up her game (or the people ahead of us walked out) because a table was freed up in the bar after about 10 minutes.

I had gallbladder surgery recently and was worried if I'd be able to find anything to stomach on the menu. I ordered the "light eater" plate - MUCH smaller than those huge combo plates - one chicken enchilada with red sauce (no cheese or sour cream) which came with black beans, rice, and salad. It was the perfect portion and didn't make me sick! Yay! I also had to watch myself with their tasty chips and salsa; very easy to go overboard with those. Everything tasted fresh and flavorful. 

My boyfriend, card-carrying member of the clean plate club, wolfed down his carne asada enchilada combo plate in no time. My friend really enjoyed her shredded beef chimichanga combo plate too. Full bellies and content tastebuds all around.

excerpts: I ordered the beef chimichanga, an enormous dish served with rice, beans, and shredded iceberg lettuce, and found it to be a bit lacking in flavor, but kind of what you expect with most shredded beef.
As promised, the margaritas were super strong, but I actually would have appreciated a bit more margarita mix, lime juice, or cointreau to cut the tequila.
chimichanga.author: Teryll H.
chimichanga.review:
I finally made it to Tia Margarita. I'd been hearing about their very strong margaritas and laid back atmosphere for quite a while and was excited to finally try it.
I loved the overflowing bowl of chips with the two types of salsas and the guacamole was pure avocados.
I ordered the beef chimichanga, an enormous dish served with rice, beans, and shredded iceberg lettuce, and found it to be a bit lacking in flavor, but kind of what you expect with most shredded beef.
As promised, the margaritas were super strong, but I actually would have appreciated a bit more margarita mix, lime juice, or cointreau to cut the tequila.

excerpts: Split a Chimichanga plate with shredded beef, refried beans, and jalapeños on side.
Sit at the bar.
Totally worth the drive from Berkeley!
Parking can be difficult on weekend nights but usually we find something along Geary.
chimichanga.author: Sarah B.
chimichanga.review:
My partner and I have been fans of Tia's for 2+ years. 

2 doubles on the rocks with salt. Split a Chimichanga plate with shredded beef, refried beans, and jalapeños on side. Sit at the bar.  Totally worth the drive from Berkeley!  Parking can be difficult on weekend nights but usually we find something along Geary. Arriving shortly before 6pm and paying a bit on the metered parking spots is a good way to do it. 

Their margaritas are the best I've had, nice and strong with freshly squeezed lime. No bogus drink mixes. And who can say no to a deep fried burrito? Drool!

excerpts: My chimichanga was a low 3 stars.
It was fairly soggy and the beans were burnt and dry.
VERY burnt.
My friend's toastda salad was an easy 2 stars, nothing impressive or tasty about it at all.
And his little brothers chicken wings were just disgusting, and for some reason, came with soy sauce.
It made no sense at all.
The service was also poor.
I had asked for tortillas and a ginger ale.
I didn't receive either and went the whole meal without anything to drink.
The highlight of the meal was the one black olive placed on top of my chimichanga.
Ironically enough my friend agreed.
chimichanga.author: David D.
chimichanga.review:
I came here with a few friends last night and we all agreed that this place just isn't up to par. In fact, its just bad. My chimichanga was a low 3 stars. It was fairly soggy and the beans were burnt and dry. VERY burnt. My friend's toastda salad was an easy 2 stars, nothing impressive or tasty about it at all. And his little brothers chicken wings were just disgusting, and for some reason, came with soy sauce. It made no sense at all. The service was also poor. I had asked for tortillas and a ginger ale. I didn't receive either and went the whole meal without anything to drink. Not even a glass of water.

The highlight of the meal was the one black olive placed on top of my chimichanga. Ironically enough my friend agreed.

excerpts: VERY GOOD chimichanga, pretty good enchiladas, good chips and salsa.
chimichanga.author: Gene M.
chimichanga.review:
I love real Mexican food. It should come from a dirty taqueria or a truck, not a sit down restaurant with a waitstaff. Burritos should be served right off the grill wrapped in foil for $5, not served on a plate with a knife and fork for $15. Mexican food is honest, and should be served as such. 

These are the reasons why I choose to never go to any sit down Mexican restaurants. But, keeping an open mind and trying new things are my forte, and I was pleasantly surprised when I was introduced to Tia Margarita.

My first thought was, "Great, another mediocre Mexican restaurant with overpriced burritos on a plate. They better have good margaritas!" The margaritas are made by hand with fresh ingredients, very good. VERY GOOD chimichanga, pretty good enchiladas, good chips and salsa. 

I'd probably only go back if a friend wanted to go there, because I like my food cheap, good, and honest, and you get that from places with a sizzling grill right next to a ringing cash register right next to a big jar of horchata right next to a sticky table top. Check out my full review on my blog, see profile.

excerpts: Between the three of us, we had chiles rellenos, enchiladas, tamales, and a chimichanga (not really Mexican, I know).
The tamales were excellent: fresh and with lots of carne.
The chiles rellenos were about a 7 on a 1-10 scale as were the enchiladas (a bit bland) and the chimichanga.
chimichanga.author: Michael W.
chimichanga.review:
I went to Tia Margarita last night with as a party of three. We started off with maragaritas which were strong and satisfying as well as only $4.95. The chips were good, but the salsa looked and tasted like it had come from a bottle...not bad, just not noteworthy.

The menu is fairly simple Sonoran fare (tacos, enchiladas, etc.). Between the three of us, we had chiles rellenos, enchiladas, tamales, and a chimichanga (not really Mexican, I know). The tamales were excellent: fresh and with lots of carne. The chiles rellenos were about a 7 on a 1-10 scale as were the enchiladas (a bit bland) and the chimichanga.

The rice was odd in that it looked and tasted like rice pilaf. It was definitely not traditional Mexican rice...although it tasted fine. The refried beans were also bit bland.

Good Mexican food in SF is very hard to find, but by SF standards, I would give this place 3.5 stars. (it would get two stars in San Diego). Still, it's worth visiting as the food, although not particularly noteworthy, is satisfying. The lively crowd is also a plus.

excerpts: My boyfriend got the chimichanga dinner which he said was just alright.
Overall, the food was sub-par, don't know if I'll be back.
Does seem like a popular place for parties, get-togethers and for families.
chimichanga.author: Jade B.
chimichanga.review: Went to this place for the first time with my boyfriend on a rainy friday night.  The place is really dim but cozy.   Wasn't in the mood for a cocktail but my boyfriend tried the strawberry margarita, I took a sip and it was pretty good.  I ended up ordering the Flautas for dinner which came with beans, rice and some salad.  The beans and rice were totally bland and the meat coming out of the side of my flautas were black!  Not very appetizing.  My boyfriend got the chimichanga dinner which he said was just alright.  Overall, the food was sub-par, don't know if I'll be back.  Does seem like a popular place for parties, get-togethers and for families.

excerpts: I ordered the Chimichanga (artery-clogging at
it's best) and it rocked!
Everyone sampled each others meals last night and everything was great.
Let me also say that their signature Margaritas were one of the best I've ever had.
They are prepared the real way without a mix.
Simply a great place to relax with friends and have a great meal or to just hang out at the bar...

chimichanga.author: Gabriel R.
chimichanga.review: Simple but fun place where you are surrounded by people who are simply out to have a wonderful time. The food was presented well, tasted great and came to us in large portions. I ordered the Chimichanga (artery-clogging at it's best) and it rocked! Everyone sampled each others meals last night and everything was great. Let me also say that their signature Margaritas were one of the best I've ever had. They are prepared the real way without a mix. Simply a great place to relax with friends and have a great meal or to just hang out at the bar...I know now why there are so many "regulars" there.

excerpts:
not the largest fan of tequila, but everyone i talk to says you still cant get a better margarita than Tommy's.

very nicely done chimichanga here at tia margarita - portions are worth the prices (which dont stray too far from Tommy's).
chimichanga.author: Darrell L.
chimichanga.review:
i like it. yes, i do.

in my opinion, better than Tommy's as far as the eats go. not the largest fan of tequila, but everyone i talk to says you still cant get a better margarita than Tommy's.

very nicely done chimichanga here at tia margarita - portions are worth the prices (which dont stray too far from Tommy's). the decor is welcoming, and nice enough, especially the bar, for a date - romantic even when you consider the candles and pretty windows. 

im still stuffed and will now go to sleep.

excerpts: I went Enchiladas Verde and found it was fine, but really the ample sour cream smothered on top is what saved it.
Black beans are cool, rice is salty, and lettuce/salsa thing is kinda strange.
enchiladas verde.author: John H.
enchiladas verde.review:
Not too shabby.  The food here isn't gonna shoot you in to a Mexican orgasm, but those calling it bland American food have never eaten at a Chi-Chi's.  The chips and mild salsa are a great start.  Usually I like hot, but the hot salsa here will leave you hurting.

I went Enchiladas Verde and found it was fine, but really the ample sour cream smothered on top is what saved it.  Black beans are cool, rice is salty, and lettuce/salsa thing is kinda strange.  Good margaritas and service was super, although there were not many there on a Sunday night.

I'd go back for the drinks, chip, and some of the food, so would recommend the bar side of things.

excerpts: Double Margarita (maybe two, hehe), Chile con queso, gambas enchiladas verde with fried egg and re-fried beans.
Add great guy, Giants-Phillies on the flat screen....and BOOM, best experience I've had here yet.
(Oh, and at initial glance entrees may seem overpriced but wait until you see how much food you get and
how bummed you are that you have
a 3 block walk i.e. waddle back to your car)
enchiladas verde.author: Angie M.
enchiladas verde.review: Now I know this is not the best mex rex, however, it's in my hood and they do have crazy strong (=good) margaritas. Here is how to make the best of eating at this mediocre mex rex (I mean that in a nice way). Double Margarita (maybe two, hehe), Chile con queso, gambas enchiladas verde with fried egg and re-fried beans. Add great guy, Giants-Phillies on the flat screen....and BOOM, best experience I've had here yet. (Oh, and at initial glance entrees may seem overpriced but wait until you see how much food you get and how bummed you are that you have a 3 block walk i.e. waddle back to your car)

excerpts: The cheese is mild and creamy.), beef taco (crispy shell, soft shell upon request; excellent tasting ground beef (shredded available, too) topped with guacamole and salsa.
taco.author: Fannie S.
taco.review:
I haven't been here in at least 9 years and glad to see that it's still around. Established in '63. 

Food = good.

Guacamole = delicious. It's not a large portion for the price but worth it. $5.75** (Some reason they did not charge us for it...must've been because they were busy?!)

Tacos Dorados = two tacos (he chose ground beef, but you can have chicken or shredded beef); comes with salad, rice and beans (black or refried). $14.50

Combination (large, 3 items) = I couldn't decide so I went with this one against my stomach's capacity. Chile relleno (excellent with a to-die-for tomato- based sauce; so many years ago this place was my first chile relleno experience!), cheese enchilada (this wasn't my favorite item, because I'm not a fan of the flour tortilla and it was all I could taste. The cheese is mild and creamy.), beef taco (crispy shell, soft shell upon request; excellent tasting ground beef (shredded available, too) topped with guacamole and salsa. $17.75

Coke = $2.00

Service = friendly and pretty fast once you get a seat. There was a 30-minute wait on a Friday night but not a surprise. They have a handwritten list that they keep track of and yes, you should wait outside, or wait at the bar with drink in hand. FYI: Host desk is inside past the bar, which is hard to see when it's as packed as it was last night. 

Prices = reasonable to moderate. Dinner for two came out to $37.21. Took home leftovers for another meal. 

Noise = boisterous. I don't recall ever being here when it was"quiet" unless it was somewhat empty, which doesn't last for long.

Overall, still a solid place for well-portioned platters, great margaritas & other drinks (didn't imbibe this time but it was prevalent throughout the dining area and the large bar area). And they still have a light eater menu.

excerpts: The food I would say was a couple steps up from Taco Bell.
Very bland and non traditional.
Empanadas were good
taco.author: Hoku L.
taco.review: Atmosphere is nice and servers friendly. The food I would say was a couple steps up from Taco Bell. Very bland and non traditional. Empanadas were good but I wouldn't call them that, also I regretted ordering them with the quesadilla as my meal was just all cheese.

excerpts:
Review on: combination plate which consisted of cheese enchilada, chicken taco, rice & black beans. 

The chicken in my "Taco Bell" shell it came in, was super dry and needed salt. 
The enchilada sauce was nothing special. 
Plus, the tortilla was still semi hard.
Rice was good.
taco.author: Worldwide ..
taco.review:
Review on: combination plate which consisted of cheese enchilada, chicken taco, rice & black beans. 

1.) The chicken in my "Taco Bell" shell it came in, was super dry and needed salt. 
2.) The enchilada sauce was nothing special. Plus, the tortilla was still semi hard.
3.) Rice was good.
4.) Black beans were okayish.

On the plus side, they do give you a nice big serving, on a huge plate. My food LOOKED good but unfortunately was not. 

I really want to give this restaurant another chance and perhaps order something else. But from experience, it seems as though, if this restaurant can't even get the most basic dishes taste good, what makes me think that their other dishes would be any better.

excerpts: Combo plate: chile relleno, taco and enchilada.
All three were above average.
Refried beans and rice were great.
This place might not win a Michelin star but I'd definitely come back and am very happy it is close to my neighborhood.
taco.author: D B.
taco.review: For what it is, this place is awesome.   The atmosphere was lively and fun.   Chips and salsa to start.   Habanero salsa is delicious.   Combo plate: chile relleno, taco and enchilada.  All three were above average.  Refried beans and rice were great.   This place might not win a Michelin star but I'd definitely come back and am very happy it is close to my neighborhood.

excerpts: The food was a step above Taco Bell.
The plates had been sitting in the window because the plates were hot and the beans crusty (yes I've worked in a restaurant before too and know how that goes).
Go to Tommy's.
taco.author: Molly W.
taco.review: I resisted the other bad reviews because this is a neighborhood spot, but now I know. The server was drunk, the bartender was the rudest person ive ever encountered (sir, your margarita was terrible. Yes I asked for extra lime juice and when you mocked me for asking in a nice way, we should have left then. You're the worst). The food was a step above Taco Bell. The plates had been sitting in the window because the plates were hot and the beans crusty (yes I've worked in a restaurant before too and know how that goes). Go to Tommy's.

excerpts: so I"m not exactly expecting some great Mexican food, but I expect more than just some scattered refried beans topped with jack cheese and a smattering of iceberg lettuce to go on my taco.
I want a legitimate taco, and what is with this ground beef business?

Ehh, not so down.

taco.author: Danny C.
taco.review: So, the food here isn't exactly great. Customer service is hit-or-miss. Drinks are the real reason why you come here because the margaritas are pretty damn strong, and they're not expensive either. The food is actually not great here. I mean, it's a Mexican place in the outer Richmond, so I"m not exactly expecting some great Mexican food, but I expect more than just some scattered refried beans topped with jack cheese and a smattering of iceberg lettuce to go on my taco. Super packed most nights, but people are mainly here for the margaritas, not the food or the ambiance. No good on either.

excerpts: Wouldn't recommend this place, you can get better food and service at Taco Bell!
taco.author: Karen S.
taco.review: Giving this place at least 1 star because we got seated right away, if it weren't for that I would definitely give no stars if that was an option.. Our waiter was a tall, average built man who looked Caucasian. He was exceptionally rude, we asked him if he can split the tab and he told us "I'll try, but my boss get anal about that" who says that?? How difficult is it to split 2 peoples tab? Obviously he has no manners. Not once did he come to refill our waters or ask if I wanted another beer, not very good at his job. Aside from that the food was garbage, the rice tastes like it was from a rice a roni box topped off with extra salt. The beans were mushy and everything overall tasted like it was from a box and just heated. Wouldn't recommend this place, you can get better food and service at Taco Bell!

excerpts: My wife had the combo of a taco and enchilada and was also excellent.
The service was great, one guy was really friendly, he looked like John Travolta as he looked in the movies Swordfish and Pulp Fiction.
He even shook my hand before we left.
Great guy !
Just dont fill up on the chips - as you near the end of one bowl of chips
another will wind up on your table.
You can easily fill up on the chips so be careful, or like us, you will be bloated and simply float home.
A little green tea will help the digestion !

Great food
Great service
Great atmosphere
We will return !!
Although I will probably not eat anything on the day we go..
taco.author: David S.
taco.review:
Dont fill up on the tortilla chips as the portions here will blow your mind. My wife and I decided to give it a try. Actually it was MY idea. I pat myself on the back.  When we entered, we had no idea where to go or wait to be seated, as it wasnt clear which way to walk. After being a little confused about where to go once inside, we got a nice table away from the bar. Yes its a bar and grill kind of a place, it was very lively and had a party like atmosphere. It was pretty noisy, but it was fun. Well it is a bar after all, not a public library. The food to me was excellent, possibly the best Mexican food Ive ever eaten. I had the Chimichonga which was just out of this world delicious, fresh, hot food, with rice and beans on a huge plate. Certainly NOT greasy. My wife had the combo of a taco and enchilada and was also excellent. The service was great, one guy was really friendly, he looked like John Travolta as he looked in the movies Swordfish and Pulp Fiction. He even shook my hand before we left. Great guy ! 
Just dont fill up on the chips - as you near the end of one bowl of chips another will wind up on your table. You can easily fill up on the chips so be careful, or like us, you will be bloated and simply float home. A little green tea will help the digestion !
Great food
Great service
Great atmosphere
We will return !! Although I will probably not eat anything on the day we go..

excerpts: I got a chile relleno/taco combo.
The relleno was not bad, it seemed fresh which is hard to come by since usually when I order one somewhere
it's obviously been prepared ahead of time and microwaved.
I would have liked it a lot more if it had Mexican cheese in it instead of jack.
Chicken taco was fine.
The rice is pretty terrible.
It tastes like rice-a-roni or some other premade rice brand.
taco.author: Karissa Q.
taco.review:
Definitely not authentic Mexican food by any means. I didn't expect much stopping in here during a bike ride considering it was in the Richmond, but we figured we would try it. The margaritas are strong, but not good. I got a chile relleno/taco combo. The relleno was not bad, it seemed fresh which is hard to come by since usually when I order one somewhere it's obviously been prepared ahead of time and microwaved. I would have liked it a lot more if it had Mexican cheese in it instead of jack. Chicken taco was fine. The rice is pretty terrible. It tastes like rice-a-roni or some other premade rice brand. My boyfriend liked his beef flauta.
The server, although nice, didn't come check on us at all and it was right before the dinner rush so it wasn't that busy yet. 
The food was acceptable and filled us up, but we probably won't be going back.

excerpts: I ordered the combination plate with a chicken enchilada, chili relleno, and a beef taco.
The food was served hot, however for me there could have been more chicken in the enchilada, more beef in the taco, and more cheese in the chili relleno.

taco.author: Robin A.

I was craving a chili relleno, and wanted to try some place new. So I plugged in the keyword Chili Relleno," and the location parameters of Inner/Outer Sunset/Richmond. This place came up with 4.5 stars.  After reading what other yelpers had to say, I decided to give this place a try.   One of the reviewer's makes indicates lack of attention to incoming patrons.  There was no host/hostess podium at the entrance.  I waited for a couple of minutes before communicating to the bartender that I'd like of be seated for dinner.  He pointed to a podium situated at the other end of the room.  There was no on standing there.  I made my way there, and was eventually seated by the hostess.

The ambiance is very dark, and did nothing for me.  I ordered the combination plate with a chicken enchilada, chili relleno, and a beef taco.  The food was served hot, however for me there could have been more chicken in the enchilada, more beef in the taco, and more cheese in the chili relleno.  Furthermore, the relleno was mostly batter.  The sauce on the enchilada did not have much flavor.  Have had much better in the Mission, and elsewhere.

taco.author: Holl T.
taco.review:
This place is WHACK. The service people are weird weird weird. As in not normal, comforting, pleasant, or enjoyable. They make me feel like they dont even want my service. Granted the last time it was a Saturday night and they were decently busy, but times are tough and this place cant afford to lose a customer! 

Unfortunately I have not tried the margaritas as crazy as that sounds. Seriously though, how freakin hard is it to make a margarita? excerpts: I had the two taco dish, one chicken and one beef, and they were both bland.
$1 for sour cream on the side??
taco.author: Jackie M.
taco.review:
Tia Margarita would be fantastic if their food was good. The restaurant and bar area is fun and charming. The light outside draws you in---unlike the Greenpeace peeps in front of my work (no offense miss). However, I was not impressed by the lackluster food. 

I had the two taco dish, one chicken and one beef, and they were both bland. $1 for sour cream on the side?? Come on now. 

Highlight of my experience here was the chips. They give you lots of them.

excerpts: I generally get the shredded beef taco or the pollo asado because they are my absolute favorites.

The service is great, and the food is always excellent. Parking in the area is a royal pain, and oftentimes there is a bit of a wait, but that doesn't stop us from going to our favorite Mexican restaurant in all of San Francisco! The margaritas will knock you out!

excerpts: I prefer my taco truck in Redwood City where I can get three incredibly delicious tacos for under $5.
taco.author: Masud K.
taco.review:
We moved into the neighborhood in March, 2011.  For an entire year now we have been eying this place.  Finally, we decided to give it a try.  We ordered a single ice margarita and some chicken tacos and a tamale.  We could not get beyond two sips of the margarita.  The food was equally bad.  I prefer my taco truck in Redwood City where I can get three incredibly delicious tacos for under $5.

Okay, my daughter insists that not all was EQUALLY bad because I stole some of her black beans ( I must have liked it to go for it, no?) AND we did enjoy the chips, salsa and guac.  This review is updated to TWO *.  If it was possible I would only give it 1.5*.

excerpts: Just don't leave without trying a shredded beef taco (or whatever you like), the queso con fresco and leaving a generous tip.
taco.author: A H.

1) Best shredded beef I've ever tasted - "EVER"
2) Queso con fresco - "YUM" - did somebody say "CHEESE!?"
3) (and this one is most important) CONSISTENCY!!

Any restaurant that can deliver and provide consistency in it's service and cuisine gets 5 stars from me.

Just don't leave without trying a shredded beef taco (or whatever you like), the queso con fresco and leaving a generous tip.  The staff actually care if you enjoy your experience there.

BLESSINGS to this family owned joint and special prayers and condolences to the family for their recent loss of their Mama.  

TIA MARGARITA - YOU ARE LOVED - YOUR TRUE FANS HAVE SPOKEN

excerpts: his relleno, his taco, my tamale and my enchilada.
I fear though that what they splurge on meats, they cut cost in spices-everything was BLAND.
taco.author: Sachi T.
taco.review:
Let me clarify: this place gets 1 star only because I can't give it zero.

Also, if you want my review in short, here it is: Mexican food for Gringos. Service is for those who enjoy watching a four-year-old tie his shoe.


Aside from the hostess practically leaving us in the dust to show us our table, our next first impression was our server asking us for our beverage order, then walking off before we could say anything...the fuck?

He got a margarita, I got a coke. The margarita was your basic margarita, nothing special. The coke was basically soda water with a splash of syrup. I didn't even know you could screw coca-cola up.

The chips were too thick for my taste, and the salsa basically reminded me of Pace Picante. 

After finishing my water with a splash of coke and my actual water, I watched our server pass our table four times before we had to ask a busser for a refill. (Apparently, they also don't do refills on soda, even though their soda comes from the bar, at the well. Cheapskates.) After finally getting her attention, she leaves our table, and elbow checks my boyfriend in the shoulder. We gave her the benefit of the doubt, that she's old and fat and maybe just lost her balance. There's no way she did that on purpose, right? I mean, seriously, right?

The ONLY redeeming quality to the food was that everything was stuffed to the max...his relleno, his taco, my tamale and my enchilada. I fear though that what they splurge on meats, they cut cost in spices-everything was BLAND. Also, the refried beans were sweet (fucking WEIRD), and I'm pretty sure they were using Uncle Ben's rice.

After we watched her screw up the next table's order, we tried asking for our check, eager to leave the stagnant memory of this shithole behind us as soon as possible. Our server motioned to us that she was going to take someone else's order first, then check us out. You bitch.

Sensing our annoyance, she cut them off in the middle of their order to tally our tab, then, when my boyfriend quickly handed her his card, she had the gall to say, "You sure? I mean, I'm human, I make mistakes." Gee, really?

After contemplating what sort of paltry amount we should leave her for a tip (if anything at all), the hostess comes over, shoves his card back in his face, and goes, "We need a new one." Uh, no bitch, what you need is a new fucking attitude.

We left that old lady no tip. If she is in fact the owner, she should put her happy ass back in the office, because as a server, she fucking blows.

I will not be returning to this pathetic excuse for traditional Mexican fare, and I will most definitely be referring people to other places.

I have never been disappointed by Mexican food (unless I go to Chevy's), but I guess there's a first for everything. 

Bottom line: This place is absolutely mediocre, and the only reason people continue to go back is because the only other option for our neighborhood is Tommy's.

excerpts: and I always get the same thing - enchilada, taco and burrito.
(I have been getting this since I was 10 years old.  :-)
taco.author: Sean O.
taco.review:
Okay, I admit I am being super generous with the five stars, but for me Tia Margarita is pure comfort food.  It reminds me of the Mexican restaurants we would get to go to growing up in the suburbs of Southern California.  I always get a combination plate and I always get the same thing - enchilada, taco and burrito.  (I have been getting this since I was 10 years old.  :-)  The plates here are huge, so I always end up taking half of it home.

Another reason I give this place five stars is that we always go with our friends that live near there and it's always a treat to see them.  They, like my partner, grew up in the city and this is a place they have gone to for years.  

So, what I am saying is that there are five very personal stars but well deserved.

excerpts: So naturally I was thrilled to get a taco/enchilada combination with a whole lotta beans and rice on quite possibly the largest plate I've ever eaten on in my life.
As D said, the size of a Toyota Corolla tire.
The enchilada was pretty good if the taco was somewhat lackluster, and D was happy with his scrambled eggs with chorizo.
The enchilada was pretty good if the taco was somewhat lackluster, and D was happy with his scrambled eggs with chorizo.
taco.author: Tanya N.
taco.review:
I've been eating with such a hungry vengeance for the past couple of days that I've half wondered if I have a tater tot in the oven.  Which would be somewhat worrisome if I could stop shoveling food into my mouth long enough to have a bout of serious contemplation.  Although I suppose the fact that it's my womyn/red tent/moon time sort of rules out potential anklebiters for the present.  And also explains why I'm starving.

So, I picked up D from work and was all, "BEANS.  NOW."  All I knew was I needed some big plate of perhaps not wholly authentic Mexican food with some cheesy beans and rice, and luck would have it that we went to Tia Margarita.

Here's the thing about me: I love the real slim shady when it comes to Mexican food, but I also have an abiding love for a tasty semi-whitey approximation of Mexican food.  So naturally I was thrilled to get a taco/enchilada combination with a whole lotta beans and rice on quite possibly the largest plate I've ever eaten on in my life.  As D said, the size of a Toyota Corolla tire.  The enchilada was pretty good if the taco was somewhat lackluster, and D was happy with his scrambled eggs with chorizo.

I had one of their fabled margaritas which I think in multiples would be  happy drunkies in a glass, and the salsa was worthwhile as well: the mild version, if a little too mild for my taste, was still quite good, and I liked that you could taste the flavor of the peppers themselves in the spicy salsa.  It's quite comfy inside Tia Margarita, and as I was trying to figure out what exactly the vibe was, D stopped grazing and pronounced solemnly, "it's like we're not in San Francisco."  Which I don't think was a slam against Tia Margarita or SF - it was a place where we could relax and shovel some good eats into our hungry mouths.

excerpts: I got the 3 item combo with the Chile Rellano, Burrito and taco.
The best part about it was the Burrito.
My boyfriend got the chicken tostada.
That was much better than my combo.
taco.author: Rachel S.
taco.review:
As a disclaimer, Tia Margarita did have wonderful chips and salsa (red salsa is bomb), and the portions were huge. 

One thing that really bums me out about San Francisco, is the lack of Mexican restaurants. I'm not talking about taquerias. I'm talking about actual Mexican restaurants. Then the ones that are here such as Tia Margarita, are mediocre. 

So I ordered a single Margarita and it tasted like pure tequila. I asked if they could make it less strong and the waitress brought out this sweet and sour mix which then made it WAY too sweet. So I ended up just not drinking it. 

The food was OK but portions were huge. I got the 3 item combo with the Chile Rellano, Burrito and taco. The best part about it was the Burrito. My boyfriend got the chicken tostada. That was much better than my combo. The Spanish rice was just eh. 

Overall, prices are reasonable for the huge portions but the food just isn't that great. Oh how I long for San Diego Mexican food...

excerpts: My friend had a combination with a crispy unsoggy taco and a burrito.
taco.author: Dan C.
taco.review:
This is my new favorite Mexican place, and not just because it is also the closest to home.

I had chicken fajitas.  My friend had a combination with a crispy unsoggy taco and a burrito.

It's tough to differentiate yourself in the Mexican food industry of San Francisco.  It mostly comes down to the chips and salsa.  This place's are tops.  

The waitress was very cool and friendly too.  I'm going back soon.

excerpts: Taco trucks are about a bizillion times better than this place.
taco.author: Lindsey G.
taco.review:
I randomly walked in with a couple of friends on a Saturday and made it to a table just before the crowds of people came in. I'm not one to dis-credit other people's tast in food, but some of the reviews have me wondering if their taste buds are in working order. 

Tia Margarita's classic margarita is probably the worst I've had. Their food was bland and super Americanized. I ordered a tostado salad which was piled about four inches high with iceberg lettuce and had a hard time locating the soggy tortilla that I can only assume was crispy b/c there was no evidence of crispness by the time it got to my table. My friends dishes were equally bland and were not worth the price they paid for it. I live only a few blocks away, but I will certainly steer clear from now on. Taco trucks are about a bizillion times better than this place.

The burrito: hot damn it is one HUGE burrito!
That's where the idea of "two meals" comes in: eat the taco and enchilada (or any other combo) and then save the burrito for another time.

taco.author: Heather S.
taco.review:
Sooooo amazing and suchhhhhh a great deal! You don't have to travel to the Mission or go as far as San Diego for some authentic Mexican food. Not diet friendly! One meal can easily suffice as two especially after diving into refillable chips and salsa. They usually provide you with two types of salsa and don't distinguish between the two, so spicy sensitive peeps be careful! 

To start I would try the shrimp and garlic. Since I discovered my aversion to garlic I haven't tried it again since but from what I remember it was de-lish! Plump shrimp with fresh garlic. 

Now the key to making two meals out of one is to order the 3 item combo plate for a couple bucks more. I usually have a burrito, taco and enchilada. The enchiladas are in a true Mexican red sauce and are oozing with cheese. The burrito: hot damn it is one HUGE burrito! That's where the idea of "two meals" comes in: eat the taco and enchilada (or any other combo) and then save the burrito for another time. Its even more delightful the next day! 

Margaritas are STRONG which often leads to a good time. I'm always groaning from a food baby when I leave this place but am so so so happy :)

excerpts: ( I typically judge a mexican place off its beans, chips, and guac, then the crispy taco, flavor of enchilada sauce, and tortilla quality)
taco.author: susan c.
taco.review:
Finally a decent place to get good mexican food AND good margaritas in SF for a reasonable price. We stumbled into this place after driving by Pizzetta 211 and seeing it was too packed. Having sworn off trying mexican food in SF after too many disappointing experiences, did I really want to give this place a chance?

I was a little hung over from the night before, and a good mexican dinner with a couple strong, tasty margaritas would really hit the spot so I thought...lets go for it.

From the moment the chips and salsa hit the table, I was sold. We got fresh, warm chips salted perfectly with 2 types of salsa which were very good. I got a 3 item combo, with excellent tasting beans. ( I typically judge a mexican place off its beans, chips, and guac, then the crispy taco, flavor of enchilada sauce, and tortilla quality) All of these things ranged from pretty good to excellent. 

From now on, this is our place when I feel like gorging myself on mexican food and margaritas. It is worth the trip....which actually wasnt too bad from Noe. Plus there is a parking lot right around the corner which only charges $1 per hour. I fundamentally have an issue paying $10 for parking on $12 mexican combo plates so the parking situation coupled with everything else makes this place ideal.

excerpts: but if what you're in the mood for is a more basic restaurant burrito, taco, etc you might find Tia more appealing.
taco.author: Ben S.
taco.review:
People in the Richmond don't have alot of choices for Mexican dining so it's no surprise when we get excited over the average fare at Tia's. Nothing wrong with the food here or the drinks but nothing deserving hyperbole either.

Large, dimly lit and casual, Tia is a fine place to bring a group of mates or your family. If you're alone, sit at the bar and talk to the locals. If you're with friends-of-friends (or worse, with your significant other's co-workers ;) ) asked to be sit up front in a booth. This is so you can see the flat-screen television, where baseball, basketball and other sports spool endlessly.

Regarding Tia vs Tommy's, without question Tommy's makes better margaritas but their food has a Yucatanean bent to it. This wonderful in it's own right but if what you're in the mood for is a more basic restaurant burrito, taco, etc you might find Tia more appealing.

Suggestions: if asked if you want hot or mild salsa get both. The hot is quite hot for some people but the mild has almost no heat (though it's tasty). For a change of pace, try the Guatemalan Tostada. It's topped with chunks of their Pollo Asada and the pineapple/sour dressing they pour over it really works well. You'll be greeted by an enormous mound of lettuce that may make you wonder if you did the right thing by listening to me, but dig deep down and you'll find there's black beans and lots of jack cheese sandwiched between two flour tortillas - more than enough substantial food to fill your tummy and then some.

excerpts: I had a chicken taco, cheese enchilada and shredded beef and bean burrito (for a combo plate, the burrito is was HUGE).
taco.author: Staci M.
taco.review:
This place was EXACTLY what I was looking for.  That's why the five stars.  

It seemed like all the Mexican places I found on Yelp were either burrito joints or sit-down restaurants with high-dollar interior Mex food.  I wanted a Mexican restaurant like the ones I grew up eating as a SoCal suburb girl.  Americanized Mexican combinations that are REALLY good.  Nothing fancy; just solid (traditional chile relleno beats out one with goat cheese and pine-nuts in my book).  A sit-down restaurant that served chips and salsa right off the bat.  Has great homemade guacamole.  And an enchilada with good enchilada sauce (not mole sauce or super-mild red sauce).  This place was perfect.  

Well, the rice IS kinda a mystery.  The flavor is like Chicken Rice-a-roni but milder.  But the beans are deliciously topped with that sizzling white cheese.  And I recommend asking them for HOT sauce.  If you mix it with the salsa they give you, it's TOPS.  

I had a chicken taco, cheese enchilada and shredded beef and bean burrito (for a combo plate, the burrito is was HUGE).  I had some of my boyfriend's chile relleno.  Everything was awesome.  The flan was perfect too.

Go here for the best mexican family restaurant I've seen yet in these parts.  It's still a BIT pricey ($15 for my 3-item combo) but I have another meal out of it and it was the bomb.  And their margaritas are nice and strong and not heavy on the mixer.  Damn this place rocks.

excerpts: 1 enchilada, 1 Taco, 1 chile relleno, 1 Fluata or 1 burrito).
taco.author: Chuy C.
taco.review:
After hearing many wonderful reviews through word of mouth I decided to finally give Tia Margarita's a try.  I figured the reviews came from trusted friends and how can you go wrong with Mexican after all I am one!

Warning numero uno. If you walk into an authentic Mexican restaurant and you and your friend are the only Mexicans in the place turn and run!

 The food at Tia Margaritas was far from appetizing; in fact it was as far from Mexican as Mexican food could be. I order the combination place (the small combo plate, you have a choice of three), which consisted of Spanish rice, refried beans, 1 enchilada, and 1 chile relleno (you have a choice of two items to go with your sides. 1 enchilada, 1 Taco, 1 chile relleno, 1 Fluata or 1 burrito).

Now I am not sure were the chef went to cooking school but it definitely did not specialize in Mexican cuisine. The Spanish rice was made with Risotto style rice, the salad came covered in Salsa, and the refried beans, basically tasted like a 50 cent can of refried beans.

The chips and so-called salsa did little for me. The salsa seemed to be made from ketchup and cocktail sauce with a hint of chopped onions.

The staff was friendly and nice and was very attending, and polite.

Unfortunately the only thing authentic about Tia Margarita's was there selection of beer.

This place should change there name to Aunt Margaret's and their Menu. Save your money and walk around the block to Gordo's.

excerpts: And in Hawaii, my homeland, we grew up with touristy Mexican food and the ever infamous Taco Bell.
But, I do know a damn good margarita when I get one.
Tia gets all 5 of my stars for their Margaritas alone.
taco.author: Kyky A.
taco.review:
I really have no good basis for critiquing Mexican food as my background is White girl/hawaiian/portuguese.  And in Hawaii, my homeland, we grew up with touristy Mexican food and the ever infamous Taco Bell.  But, I do know a damn good margarita when I get one.  Tia gets all 5 of my stars for their Margaritas alone.  Freshly made, no nasty mixers, and a great selection of Te"kill"ya!

Parking sucks so plan on parking far away on a busy night or carpooling.  I would take off a star for this normally but, not with Tia because it's really not their fault and if there were any more parking than there would be way too many people.

I love the food and the family vibe/family run feeling of this place too.

excerpts: The taco shells were just regular pre-folded corn tortillas, the kind you get at the grocery store in a box, but it was OK because the shredded beef was GOOD.
It was the kind of shredded beef that's very flavorful from soaking in salty tomato-y sauce for a long time.
The tacos were covered with some of that salsa-like tomato dressing that Mexican restaurants put on their salads, and a big ol' scoop of guacamole.
Yum!
There was one black olive for garnish.

taco.author: Lorelei S.
taco.review:
This place?  It's OK.  Just OK.

It's dark inside, so dark you can barely see your food, which is I guess atmospheric.  There are wraught iron thingies in the fake windows between rooms, some stained glass, and big ol' hanging ceiling of what looks like mirrored glass over the bar.  The whole first dining room is just tables ringed around the bar.  I guess the margaritas are important here.  I didn't have one.

The service was quick and businesslike.  The chips they brought were mostly crunched into small pieces but they were good.  The salsa was like pureed tomatos; very little spice.  Fortunately I like mild salsa so I was pretty happy with it.

I ordered a combo plate with two shredded beef tacos.  The refried beans were not great.  They have this certain taste, maybe it's chili or something but it's a taste I do not like in my beans.  I like my refritos salty and beany.  There was plenty of cheese melted on top of the beans though; I moved the beany cheese over to the rice and ate it together to give it some flavor.  The rice wasn't very much like the spanish rice I'm used to in Mexican restaurants; it was pretty much plain white rice.  So, rice and beans, eh.

The tacos were really good!  The taco shells were just regular pre-folded corn tortillas, the kind you get at the grocery store in a box, but it was OK because the shredded beef was GOOD.  It was the kind of shredded beef that's very flavorful from soaking in salty tomato-y sauce for a long time.  The tacos were covered with some of that salsa-like tomato dressing that Mexican restaurants put on their salads, and a big ol' scoop of guacamole.  Yum!  There was one black olive for garnish.  And the whole shmear was piled atop a big stack of lettuce with tomato dressing.  I couldn't finish all the salad but it was pretty good too.

All in all, this is a decent place to get shredded beef tacos, but not rice and beans, and I'd rather go to Tommy's.  Tommy's was closed tonight which is how I ended up at Tia Margarita's, but I don't know when I'll go back.

excerpts: Portions are large and my wife and mother in law each ordered a single taco with the works and that was plenty for them.
taco.author: Richard H.
taco.review: For whatever reason, I never had the impetus to dine at this restaurant even though I grew up in the Richmond District. I'm now making up for lost time as my family first dined here during the Christmas holidays and we were all amazed at the food that this family run restaurant puts out!. I used to be a La Barca fan back when the food was good 20 plus years ago and had been looking for a family style Mexican restaurnat in this neighborhood. The place was still hopping after 9 pm and the margaritas were a killer as many yelpers can attest! I came back a second time within the past month for dinner again and was not dismayed. Portions are large and my wife and mother in law each ordered a single taco with the works and that was plenty for them. On the other hand, I ordered the 3 item combo which included 2 enchiladas and the burrito and was not disappointed. The male server from our first visit remembered me and acknowledged that "we had come back" which was nice. I happened to strike up a conversation with the hostess as I am also in the food business and introduced myself as having been a neighborhood resident. She told me that her parents opened the business back in the 50's which I knew.  I can't remember her name but I will definitely be back when I'm in the city!

tamale.author: Larry H.
tamale.review: What's wrong with the food at Tia Margarita's?  It's SLOP, not fit for a trough!  Typical Mexican restaurant microwaved soup (refried beans), tasteless rice, and some shredded lettuce.  The cheese enchiladas were stuffed thick with some foreign kind of salty cheese then smothered with some orange-colored paste (their enchilada sauce).  My tamale was a gigantic, cold lump of off-colored corn meal about 2-3 inches thick and I could barely find the meat.  (Sent it back for another cheese enchilada -- big mistake!)  The tamale had its own horrible sauce, too.  I can't describe what they called a chile relleno --some greasy, soggy pancake that had a chile in it somewhere.  Horrible!  About an hour after eating, I was so bloated -- like I swallowed a salt lick -- it was unbelievable.  I suffered from severe gas all night long and the next morning, then suffered from constipation for the next full day.  The margaritas were delicious, however.  Go there (if you can ever find a parking place) only for a couple margaritas, friendly bartenders, and some chips and salsa but pass on any food!

tamale.review:
Came here with a few friends about an hour before closing. Seated very quickly. We sat in the room with the bar and were able to watch the Giants game while we ate. 

I ordered a house margarita on the rocks and it was really good. The pictures on yelp of the margarita are accurate. 

I ordered the Combination Plate (Large). This plate came with a Chile Relleno that is possibly the best I have ever had, highly recommended. The plate also came with a carne Asada burrito, a chicken enchilada, and a tamale. All of the food was very tasty and very filling. So much so, had to take some of it home for breakfast in the morning. 

The service was good. We had a waiter that took out orders and was prompt with everything we needed and the hostess kinda backed him up and made sure when he was busy at other tables, we were taken cared of. 

If you like good quality food and great service I would recommend this place. I'm sure I'll be back again to visit soon.

excerpts: My wife and I will go and split a large combination plate (which gives you a choice of 3 items - tamale, burrito, enchilada, chile relleno, etc.).

tamale.author: dave g.
tamale.review:
Tia's Rocks!
I can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet because I've eaten here at least 10 times.  I've been with friends, family, co-workers, everyone loves this place.  First thing you need to know is that the food is TASTY!  We've probably gone thru everything on the menu at this point and have never been disappointed.   It's one of our favorite places to eat in the city.

The portions are HUGE!  My wife and I will go and split a large combination plate (which gives you a choice of 3 items - tamale, burrito, enchilada, chile relleno, etc.).  It's perfect because you can try a bunch of stuff and it's only around $15.  Not only have we both been full off of that plate, but we can still bring leftovers home for another meal.  Rockin'!  

My buddy ordered a small combination plate and that came with TWO burritos!  Nice.  I read where some people were bitching about the prices, but, the food you get will feed an army.

Next, the Margaritas are great.  We had a group of 5 there tonight and everyone commented on how tasty they were.  I read a few reviews where people felt they were watered down, but I've never thought that once in all the Margaritas I've had there over the years.  In fact, sometimes I thought they were TOO strong.  (I mean, it can't really ever be TOO strong, but, ya know what I mean). 

The wait staff there is great.  We had chips and salsa on our table within moments of being seated.  They're quick to fill back up your water, they're generous with the chips and salsa and constantly come around to make sure you have everything you need.  After years of going, I finally introduced myself to the same waitress who has waited on us so many times.  Her name is Rosa and she's awesome.  She's got a great sense of humor and we love joking around with her.  I already can't wait to go back....

tamale.review:
I've always wondered about this place and finally decided to go give it a try last month or so after getting so tired of the regular taqueria food near my work place.

Once we walked in, we were greeted with the lovely old lady who I think is the owner. The atmosphere seemed really relaxing and I knew my dinner is gonna be amazing.

Started with some chips and salsa and chips and queso... Chips were served warm and salsa was a bite mild but not overly spicy.. I love how you can eat as much chips as you want because they just keep bring you more after your basket is done. The cheese was delicious.. It was very tasty, stringy, and yummy!

We kinda shared our entrees. So entrees included:
Chef's special-Pollo Asado, carne asada, and gambas (there was SO MUCH food on this plate it's crazy!)

The pollo (chicken) was thinly cut and served with scallions on top with a tangy marinade.. The chicken was not DRY and the flavor was great.

Carne asada (steak) had a little lime marinade with sauteed onions and chiles.

Gambas (shrimp) My favorite one on the plate! Lots of butter and garlic. YUM! 

Served with refried beans and rice.

Then there was the tamales. AMAZING tamales! They know how to make some good fucken tamales.. They are HUGE and yummy. Filled with lots of meat and my favorite part in a tamale is the corn shell, it was thick! That means there was a lot of corn shell for me to eat.!! 

Didn't try the margaritas but definitely will next time.

Great service, great atmosphere, great food = 5 stars! *****

tamale.author: Sachi T.
tamale.review:
Let me clarify: this place gets 1 star only because I can't give it zero.

Also, if you want my review in short, here it is: Mexican food for Gringos. Service is for those who enjoy watching a four-year-old tie his shoe.


Aside from the hostess practically leaving us in the dust to show us our table, our next first impression was our server asking us for our beverage order, then walking off before we could say anything...the fuck?

He got a margarita, I got a coke. The margarita was your basic margarita, nothing special. The coke was basically soda water with a splash of syrup. I didn't even know you could screw coca-cola up.

The chips were too thick for my taste, and the salsa basically reminded me of Pace Picante. 

After finishing my water with a splash of coke and my actual water, I watched our server pass our table four times before we had to ask a busser for a refill. (Apparently, they also don't do refills on soda, even though their soda comes from the bar, at the well. Cheapskates.) After finally getting her attention, she leaves our table, and elbow checks my boyfriend in the shoulder. We gave her the benefit of the doubt, that she's old and fat and maybe just lost her balance. There's no way she did that on purpose, right? I mean, seriously, right?

The ONLY redeeming quality to the food was that everything was stuffed to the max...his relleno, his taco, my tamale and my enchilada. I fear though that what they splurge on meats, they cut cost in spices-everything was BLAND. Also, the refried beans were sweet (fucking WEIRD), and I'm pretty sure they were using Uncle Ben's rice.

After we watched her screw up the next table's order, we tried asking for our check, eager to leave the stagnant memory of this shithole behind us as soon as possible. Our server motioned to us that she was going to take someone else's order first, then check us out. You bitch.

Sensing our annoyance, she cut them off in the middle of their order to tally our tab, then, when my boyfriend quickly handed her his card, she had the gall to say, "You sure? I mean, I'm human, I make mistakes." Gee, really?

After contemplating what sort of paltry amount we should leave her for a tip (if anything at all), the hostess comes over, shoves his card back in his face, and goes, "We need a new one." Uh, no bitch, what you need is a new fucking attitude.

We left that old lady no tip. If she is in fact the owner, she should put her happy ass back in the office, because as a server, she fucking blows.

I will not be returning to this pathetic excuse for traditional Mexican fare, and I will most definitely be referring people to other places.

I have never been disappointed by Mexican food (unless I go to Chevy's), but I guess there's a first for everything. 

Bottom line: This place is absolutely mediocre, and the only reason people continue to go back is because the only other option for our neighborhood is Tommy's.
